titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the European Print File
circa 1750-1920
PR 151

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 15:49:02 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: This collection contains approximately 500 European prints, ca. 1750-1920. Most are nineteenth century British or French commercially produced prints, but Italian, German and Dutch prints are also represented.
did.physloc: Materials in this collection may be stored offsite. For more information on making arrangements to consult them, please visit www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.
did.langmaterial: This collection is primarily visual. Any text is likely to be in English, French, Italian, German, and Dutch.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Materials in this collection may be stored offsite. For more information on making arrangements to consult them, please visit www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as: European Print File, PR 151, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was removed from the Subject File (PR-068) and the Graphic Arts File (PR-022) in 2002.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains approximately 500 European prints, ca. 1750-1920. Most are nineteenth century British or French commercially produced prints, but Italian, German and Dutch prints are also represented. They include lithographs, chromolithographs, etchings, engravings and photogravures. Many are chromolithographs printed as newspaper and magazine supplements, or as advertisements, including several of Pears Soap's annual advertisements. Other materials include prints of historical or military subjects, genre scenes or religious scenes, many after C.R. Eastlake, and advertisements for music concerts. There are also plates from several books: Cuvier's "Animal Kingdom;" illustrations to Dickens and Shakespeare, many after C.R. Leslie; Cruikshank's six illustrations to the 1828 edition of "John Gilpin;" William Henry Pyne's "Microcosm," a study of occupations; engravings after John Hayter from "Beauties of the Court of Queen Victoria" (1850). Also included are 2 copies of French printmaker Paul Cesar Helleu's "Portrait of a Woman."

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Taking images of documents from the library collections for reference purposes by using hand-held cameras and in accordance with the library's photography guidelines is encouraged. As an alternative, patrons may request up to 20 images per day from staff.

Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.

Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions
